title: SB 740
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Sonoma County Board of Supervisors may authorize an increase in fees for marriage licenses and confidential marriage licenses, up to $2, to oversee agencies dealing with domestic violence. An annual increase based on the Consumer Price Index for the San Francisco area is also allowed. In Sonoma County, fees for marriage licenses may be increased to fund domestic violence prevention efforts. The Board of Supervisors must submit reports on funds received and outcomes achieved. Sonoma County Board of Supervisors may authorize an increase in fees for certified copies of marriage certificates, fetal death records, and death records to fund domestic violence prevention efforts. The increase is limited to a maximum of two dollars ($2) and will be in effect until January 1, 2021, unless extended by a later statute. The Sonoma County Board of Supervisors may authorize an annual increase in fees for certified copies of marriage certificates, fetal death records, and death records based on the Consumer Price Index. Applicants must pay additional fees established by the Board. This section will be in effect until January 1, 2021, unless extended by a later statute. The Sonoma County Board of Supervisors will direct fees collected for certain certificates into a special fund. The county may retain up to 4 percent of the fund for administrative costs related to collecting and depositing additional fees. The fund will support oversight and coordination of domestic violence prevention efforts among various agencies in Sonoma County. Section 59111 of the Food and Agricultural Code in Sonoma County is amended to address domestic violence prevention efforts. This section will be repealed on January 1, 2021, unless extended by a later statute. Upon the issuance of a marketing order or agreement, a notice must be posted on a public bulletin board and the department's website. The order or agreement will not take effect until five days after posting. Notices must also be mailed to those directly affected by the terms. Upon issuance of a marketing order or agreement, a notice must be posted publicly and on the department's website. The order will take effect five days after posting. Notices must also be mailed to those directly affected. Requests for the notice can be filed in the office of the secretary. The termination of any marketing order or agreement under Section 59087 is exempt from this section.
